Lebesgue Measure

Outer Measure

  • The (Lebesgue) outer measure of a set S⊆RS \subseteq \mathbb{R}S⊆R is the infimum of the length of its interval-covers: m∗(S)=inf⁡ZS, where ZS={Λ({Ii}):⋃iIi⊇S}m^{*}(S)= \inf Z_{S},\, \text{where }Z_{S}=\left\{\Lambda(\{ I_{i} \}):\bigcup_{i}I_{i} \supseteq S \right\}m∗(S)=infZS​,where ZS​={Λ({Ii​}):i⋃​Ii​⊇S}If ZSZ_{S}ZS​ is unbounded, set m∗=∞m^{*}=\inftym∗=∞.

  • Outer measures preserve orders: if A⊆BA \subseteq BA⊆B, then m∗(A)≤m∗(B)m^{*}(A) \le m^{*}(B)m∗(A)≤m∗(B).

  • Outer measures are countably subadditive: given sequence of sets (En)(E_{n})(En​), m∗(∪nEn)≤∑nm∗(En)m^{*}(\cup_{n} E_{n}) \le \sum_{n} m^{*}(E_{n})m∗(∪n​En​)≤n∑​m∗(En​)

Proof: if RHS=∞\mathrm{RHS}=\inftyRHS=∞, the result is trivial, so assume otherwise.
It’s sufficient to show that for any ϵ>0\epsilon > 0ϵ>0, m∗(∪nEn)≤∑nm∗(En)+ϵm^{*}(\cup_{n} E_{n}) \le \sum_{n} m^{*}(E_{n})+\epsilonm∗(∪n​En​)≤n∑​m∗(En​)+ϵFor each EnE_{n}En​, find interval-cover {Ii(n)}:Λ({Ii(n)})≤m∗(En)+ϵ2−n\{ I^{(n)}_{i} \}: \Lambda(\{ I_{i}^{(n)} \}) \le m^{*}(E_{n})+\epsilon 2^{-n}{Ii(n)​}:Λ({Ii(n)​})≤m∗(En​)+ϵ2−n.
Then their union J=∪n{Ii(n)}J=\cup_{n}\{ I^{(n)}_{i} \}J=∪n​{Ii(n)​} is a countable interval-cover of ∪nEn\cup_{n}E_{n}∪n​En​, with length Λ(J)=∑nΛ({Ii(n)})≤∑n(m∗(En)+ϵ2−n)≤(∑nm∗(En))+ϵ\Lambda(J)=\sum_{n}\Lambda(\{ I^{(n)}_{i} \})\le \sum_{n}\left(m^{*}(E_{n})+\epsilon 2^{-n}\right)\le\left(\sum_{n}m^{*}(E_{n})\right)+\epsilonΛ(J)=n∑​Λ({Ii(n)​})≤n∑​(m∗(En​)+ϵ2−n)≤(n∑​m∗(En​))+ϵSo m∗(∪nEn)≤Λ(J)≤∑nm∗(En)+ϵm^{*}(\cup_{n}E_{n}) \le \Lambda(J) \le \sum_{n} m^{*}(E_{n})+\epsilonm∗(∪n​En​)≤Λ(J)≤∑n​m∗(En​)+ϵ.

Null Sets

  • A set S⊆RS \subseteq \mathbb{R}S⊆R is null or a null set if has outer measure of m∗(S)=0m^{\ast}(S)=0m∗(S)=0.
  • Equivalently, it is contained by a sequence of intervals of arbitrarily small (total) length: ∀ϵ>0,∃(Ii):Λ((Ii))<ϵ, S⊆⋃i=1∞Ii\forall \epsilon>0, \exists (I_{i}): \Lambda((I_{i})) < \epsilon,\, S \subseteq \bigcup_{i=1}^{\infty}I_{i}∀ϵ>0,∃(Ii​):Λ((Ii​))<ϵ,S⊆i=1⋃∞​Ii​

Proof of equivalence is just manipulating the definition of m∗m^{\ast}m∗ as an infimum.

  • Countable unions of null sets are also null: if S1,S2,…S_{1},S_{2},\dotsS1​,S2​,… are all null, then T=∪i=1∞SiT=\cup_{i=1}^{\infty}S_{i}T=∪i=1∞​Si​ is also null.
    • Hence singletons, finite sets, and countable sets are all null.

Proof: Let {Ik(i)}\{ I_{k}^{(i)} \}{Ik(i)​} be an interval cover of SiS_{i}Si​ with total length Λ({Ik(i)})<ϵ2−i\Lambda(\{ I_{k}^{(i)} \})< \epsilon 2^{-i}Λ({Ik(i)​})<ϵ2−i.
Then their union ∪i{Ik(i)}\cup_{i}\{ I^{(i)}_{k}\}∪i​{Ik(i)​} is a countable interval cover of TTT. Its total length is ∑i∑kIk(i)<∑iϵ2−i=ϵ\sum_{i}\sum_{k}I^{(i)}_{k}<\sum_{i} \epsilon 2^{-i}=\epsilon∑i​∑k​Ik(i)​<∑i​ϵ2−i=ϵ.

  • Uncountable sets can also be null: for example the Cantor set is uncountable but null.

  • Union with a null set does not change the measure.

Proof: say A,E⊆RA,E \subseteq \mathbb{R}A,E⊆R, and EEE null. Then m∗(A∪E)≤m∗(A)+m∗(E)0≤m∗(A∪E)m^{*}(A \cup E)\le m^{*}(A)+\underset{0}{\cancel{m^{*}(E)}}\le m^{*}(A \cup E)m∗(A∪E)≤m∗(A)+0m∗(E)​​≤m∗(A∪E)where the first inequality is from subadditivity, and the second is from preserving the order A⊆A∪EA \subseteq A \cup EA⊆A∪E.

Consistency of Outer Measure and Length

  • If I=[a,b]I=[a,b]I=[a,b] is a closed interval, m∗(I)=l(I)m^{*}(I)=l(I)m∗(I)=l(I).

Proof: (≤\le≤) trivial: {I}∈ZI\{ I \} \in Z_{I}{I}∈ZI​ covers III.
(≥\ge≥) the approximation property gives a cover {Ii}:Λ(Ii)≤m∗(I)+ϵ\{I_{i} \}: \Lambda(I_{i}) \le m^{*}(I) + \epsilon{Ii​}:Λ(Ii​)≤m∗(I)+ϵ.
Extend each of IiI_{i}Ii​ by ±2−iϵ\pm 2^{-i}\epsilon±2−iϵ to get open intervals JiJ_{i}Ji​, another cover of III with Λ({Ji})≤m∗(I)+3ϵ\Lambda(\{ J_{i} \}) \le m^{*}(I) + 3 \epsilonΛ({Ji​})≤m∗(I)+3ϵ.
Heine-Borel gives a finite subcover {Jj=(cj,dj)}j=1k\{ J_{j}=(c_{j},d_{j}) \}_{j=1}^{k}{Jj​=(cj​,dj​)}j=1k​.
Let c=min⁡{cj},d=max⁡{dj}c=\min \{ c_{j} \},d=\max \{ d_{j} \}c=min{cj​},d=max{dj​} be the two endpoints of {Jj}j=1k\{ J_{j} \}_{j=1}^{k}{Jj​}j=1k​, so that c<a<b<dc<a<b<dc<a<b<d. Then (b−a)<(d−c)<Λ({Jj}j=1k)≤Λ({Ji})≤m∗(I)+3ϵ(b-a)<(d-c)<\Lambda(\{ J_{j} \}_{j=1}^{k}) \le \Lambda(\{ J_{i} \})\le m^{*}(I)+3\epsilon(b−a)<(d−c)<Λ({Jj​}j=1k​)≤Λ({Ji​})≤m∗(I)+3ϵSince ϵ\epsilonϵ can be arbitrarily small, l(I)=(b−a)≤m∗(I)l(I)=(b-a) \le m^*(I)l(I)=(b−a)≤m∗(I).

  • In general, if III is any interval, m∗(I)=l(I)m^{*}(I)=l(I)m∗(I)=l(I).

Proof: if III unbounded, the result is trivial.
If I=[a,b)I=[a,b)I=[a,b), union with the null set {b}\{ b \}{b} changes neither the length or the outer measure. So the previous result applies to [a,b)∪{b}=[a,b][a,b)\cup \{ b \}=[a,b][a,b)∪{b}=[a,b].
Similarly for (a,b](a,b](a,b], (a,b)(a,b)(a,b).

Measurable Sets and the Lebesgue Measure

Big idea: the outer measure fails for bad sets. The Lebesgue measurable sets are the good sets. The Lebesgue measure is the outer measure restricted to those good sets.

  • The problem with the outer measure m∗:P(R)→Rm^{\ast}:\mathcal{P}(\mathbb{R})\to \mathbb{R}m∗:P(R)→R is that it is not countably additive, where there exists a countable sequence of disjoint sets (An)(A_{n})(An​) such that m∗(∪nAn)⪇∑nm∗(An)m^{\ast}(\cup_{n}A_{n})\lneq \sum_{n}m^{\ast}(A_{n})m∗(∪n​An​)⪇n∑​m∗(An​)see Example 2.4\text{Example }2.4Example 2.4 on page 7 of the 2022-23 lecture notes. We need to restrict the measure to sets with better behavior–the Lebesgue measruable sets.

  • A set EEE is (Lebesgue) measurable if for any A⊆RA \subseteq \mathbb{R}A⊆R, m∗(A)=m∗(A∩E)+m∗(A∩Ec)m^{*}(A)=m^{*}(A \cap E)+m^{*}(A \cap E^{c})m∗(A)=m∗(A∩E)+m∗(A∩Ec)The set of Lebesgue measurable sets is denoted MLeb\mathcal{M}_{Leb}MLeb​.

    • To show measurability, since LHS≤RHS\mathrm{LHS}\le\mathrm{RHS}LHS≤RHS is guaranteed, it’s sufficient to show LHS≥RHS\mathrm{ LHS} \ge \mathrm{RHS}LHS≥RHS.

  • MLeb\mathcal{M}_{Leb}MLeb​ is a σ\sigmaσ-field in R\mathbb{R}R, meaning that:

    • (1) R∈M\mathbb{R} \in \mathcal{M}R∈M,
    • (2) closed to complements: if E∈ME \in \mathcal{M}E∈M, then Ec∈ME^{c}\in \mathcal{M}Ec∈M,
    • (3) closed to countable unions: if (En)n=1∞⊆M(E_{n})_{n=1}^{\infty} \subseteq \mathcal{M}(En​)n=1∞​⊆M, then ∪nEn∈M\cup_{n}E_{n } \in \mathcal{M}∪n​En​∈M.

  • Null sets and intervals are measurable.

  • Since all open sets are countable unions of open intervals, all open sets are measurable.

Both proved in Sheet 1.

  • When restricted to MLeb\mathcal{M}_{Leb}MLeb​, the outer measure is denoted m:MLeb→Rm:\mathcal{M}_{Leb} \to \mathbb{R}m:MLeb​→R, the Lebesgue measure.

Properties of the Lebesgue Measure

Big idea: the Lebesgue measure works!

  • The Lebesgue measure is countably additive: if (En)n=1∞⊆MLeb(E_{n})_{n=1}^{\infty} \subseteq \mathcal{M}_{Leb}(En​)n=1∞​⊆MLeb​ are pairwise disjoint, then m(∪nEn)=∑nm(En)m(\cup_{n} E_{n}) = \sum_{n} m(E_{n})m(∪n​En​)=n∑​m(En​)

Proof: by subadditivity, it’s sufficient to show that LHS≥RHS\mathrm{LHS} \ge \mathrm{RHS}LHS≥RHS. Suppose for contradiction LHS<RHS\mathrm{LHS}<\mathrm{RHS}LHS<RHS.
Since the partial sums of RHS=lim⁡N→∞∑n=1Nm(En)\mathrm{RHS}=\lim_{ N \to \infty }\sum_{n=1}^{N}m(E_{n})RHS=limN→∞​∑n=1N​m(En​) are non-decreasing, there must be an NNN when the partial sum surpasses LHS\mathrm{LHS}LHS: ∃N:m(∪nEn)<∑n=1Nm(En)(∗)\begin{align*} \exists N:m(\cup_{n}E_{n})<\sum_{n=1}^{N}m(E_{n}) && (*) \end{align*}∃N:m(∪n​En​)<n=1∑N​m(En​)​​(∗)​Apply the definition of measurability of EnE_{n}En​ to get m(∪nEn)=m(E1∩(∪nEn))+m(E1C∩(∪nEn))=m(E1)+m(∪n≥2En)=m(E1)+m(E2)+m(∪n≥3En)…=∑n=1Nm(En)+m(∪n≥N+1En)\begin{align*} m(\cup_{n}E_{n})&= m\big( E_{1} \cap (\cup_{n}E_{n}) \big) + m\big( E_{1}^{C} \cap (\cup_{n}E_{n}) \big)\\ &= m(E_{1})+m(\cup_{n \ge 2}E_{n})\\ &= m(E_{1})+m(E_{2})+m(\cup_{n \ge 3}E_{n}) \\ &\dots\\ &= \sum_{n=1}^{N}m(E_{n})+m(\cup_{n \ge N+1}E_{n}) \end{align*}m(∪n​En​)​=m(E1​∩(∪n​En​))+m(E1C​∩(∪n​En​))=m(E1​)+m(∪n≥2​En​)=m(E1​)+m(E2​)+m(∪n≥3​En​)…=n=1∑N​m(En​)+m(∪n≥N+1​En​)​but then plugging back into (∗)(*)(∗) gives m(∪n≥N+1En)<0m(\cup_{n \ge N+1}E_{n})< 0m(∪n≥N+1​En​)<0, a contradiction.

  • For any E∈MLebE \in \mathcal{M}_{Leb}E∈MLeb​, it can be arbitrarily well-fit into some open set: ∀ϵ>0,∃O open⊆R: E⊆O, m(O−E)<ϵ\forall \epsilon>0,\exists O \text{ open} \subseteq \mathbb{R}:\,E \subseteq O,\,m(O-E)<\epsilon∀ϵ>0,∃O open⊆R:E⊆O,m(O−E)<ϵNote that it is not one-set-fits-all-ϵ\epsilonϵ.

Proof:
Finite measure: assume m(E)<∞m(E)<\inftym(E)<∞. Find an interval cover {Ii}\{ I_{i} \}{Ii​} of AAA with total length less than m∗(A)+ϵm^{*}(A)+\epsilonm∗(A)+ϵ.
Extend each InI_{n}In​ by ϵ/2n\epsilon / 2^nϵ/2n to get the open interval-cover {Ji}:Λ({Ji})<m(E)+2ϵ\{ J_{i} \}:\Lambda(\{ J_{i} \})<m(E)+2\epsilon{Ji​}:Λ({Ji​})<m(E)+2ϵ. Then take the union O=∪iJiO=\cup_{i}J_{i}O=∪i​Ji​.
Apply the definition of E∈MLebE \in \mathcal{M}_{Leb}E∈MLeb​ to verify m(O−E)<ϵm(O-E)<\epsilonm(O−E)<ϵ.

Infinite measure: assume m(E)=∞m(E)=\inftym(E)=∞, then define En=E∩[−n,n]E_{n}=E \cap [-n,n]En​=E∩[−n,n]. Fit open sets On⊃En:m(On−En)<ϵ2−nO_{n}\supset E_{n}:m(O_{n}-E_{n})<\epsilon 2^{-n}On​⊃En​:m(On​−En​)<ϵ2−n.
Then take O≡∪nOn⊃EO \equiv \cup_{n}O_{n} \supset EO≡∪n​On​⊃E, so that O−E=∪n(On−En)O-E=\cup_{n}(O_{n}-E_{n})O−E=∪n​(On​−En​).
By subadditivity m(O−E)≤∑nm(On−En)<∑nϵ2−n=ϵm(O-E) \le \sum_{n}m(O_{n}-E_{n})<\sum_{n}\epsilon 2^{-n}=\epsilonm(O−E)≤∑n​m(On​−En​)<∑n​ϵ2−n=ϵ.

  • If (An)⊂M(A_{n}) \subset \mathcal{M}(An​)⊂M, and An⊂An+1A_{n} \subset A_{n+1}An​⊂An+1​, then m(⋃nAn)=lim⁡n→∞m(An)m(\bigcup_{n}A_{n})=\lim_{ n \to \infty }m(A_{n})m(⋃n​An​)=limn→∞​m(An​).
    • This property is used in a number of proofs in A8 Probability.

Proof: define Bn=An−An−1B_{n}=A_{n}-A_{n-1}Bn​=An​−An−1​, then ∪nAn=∪nBn\cup_{n}A_{n}=\cup_{n}B_{n}∪n​An​=∪n​Bn​, and apply countable additivity to the disjoint (Bn)(B_{n})(Bn​).

Completions

  • A measure space (R,A,μ)(\mathbb{R}, \mathcal{A}, \mu)(R,A,μ) is complete if any μ\muμ-null subset N∈A:μ(N)=0N \in \mathcal{A}: \mu(N)=0N∈A:μ(N)=0 has its subsets included too: M⊂N⇒M∈AM \subset N \Rightarrow M \in \mathcal{A}M⊂N⇒M∈A.
  • For a (incomplete) measure space (R,A,μ)(\mathbb{R},\mathcal{A},\mu)(R,A,μ), its completion is the space (R,C,μˉ)(\mathbb{R}, \mathcal{C}, \bar{\mu})(R,C,μˉ​), where C\mathcal{C}C is the smallest σ\sigmaσ-field containing B\mathcal{B}B that is complete, and μˉ\bar{\mu}μˉ​ is the unique extension of μ\muμ to C\mathcal{C}C.
  • M\mathcal{M}M is the completion of B\mathcal{B}B.

Proof: M\mathcal{M}M is obviously one complete space containing B\mathcal{B}B. To see that it’s minimal, we show that M⊆C\mathcal{M}\subseteq \mathcal{C}M⊆C, the completion of B\mathcal{B}B.

For any E∈ME \in \mathcal{M}E∈M, first suppose m(E)m(E)m(E) finite; approximate it with B=∩nOn∈B:m(B)=m(E)B= \cap_{n}O_{n} \in \mathcal{B}:m(B)=m(E)B=∩n​On​∈B:m(B)=m(E). Then approximate N=B−EN=B-EN=B−E with L∈B:m(L)=m(N)=0L \in \mathcal{B}:m(L)=m(N)=0L∈B:m(L)=m(N)=0. Hence NNN is a subset of the null set LLL of B\mathcal{B}B, N∈CN \in \mathcal{C}N∈C, so does E=B−NE = B - NE=B−N.
If m(E)m(E)m(E) is instead infinite, it is the countable union of (En):En=E∩[−n,n]∈C(E_{n}): E_{n}=E \cap [-n,n] \in \mathcal{C}(En​):En​=E∩[−n,n]∈C, so E∈CE \in \mathcal{C}E∈C again. Hence M⊆CM \subseteq \mathcal{C}M⊆C.

Measurable Spaces

  • The Lebesgue measure mmm in R\mathbb{R}R can be generalized to other spaces, giving measure functions with similar properties.

General Measurable Spaces

  • Given a set Ω\OmegaΩ, a σ\sigmaσ-algebra (or σ\sigmaσ-field) is a set F⊆P(Ω)\mathcal{F} \subseteq \mathcal{P}(\Omega)F⊆P(Ω) if:
    • (1) Ω∈F\Omega \in \mathcal{F}Ω∈F,
    • (2) closed to complements: if E∈FE \in \mathcal{F}E∈F, then Ec∈FE^{c}\in \mathcal{F}Ec∈F,
    • (3) closed to countable unions: if (En)n=1∞⊆F(E_{n})_{n=1}^{\infty} \subseteq \mathcal{F}(En​)n=1∞​⊆F, then ∪nEn∈F\cup_{n}E_{n } \in \mathcal{F}∪n​En​∈F.
  • Then the pair (Ω,F)(\Omega, \mathcal{F})(Ω,F) is called a measurable space.
  • A measure μ:F→[0,∞]\mu:\mathcal{F} \to [0, \infty]μ:F→[0,∞] in the space (Ω,F)(\Omega,\mathcal{F})(Ω,F) satisfies:
    • μ(∅)=0\mu(\emptyset)=0μ(∅)=0,
    • countable additivity: pairwise disjoint sets (En)n=0∞⊆F(E_{n})_{n=0}^{\infty}\subseteq \mathcal{F}(En​)n=0∞​⊆F have μ(∪nEn)=∑nμ(En)\mu(\cup_{n}E_{n})=\sum_{n}\mu(E_{n})μ(∪n​En​)=∑n​μ(En​).
  • A measure is finite if μ(Ω)<∞\mu(\Omega) < \inftyμ(Ω)<∞, and a probability measure if μ(Ω)=1\mu(\Omega)=1μ(Ω)=1.
  • The triple (Ω,F,μ)(\Omega, \mathcal{F}, \mu)(Ω,F,μ) is a measure space.
    • For example, (R,M,m)(\mathbb{R}, \mathcal{M},m)(R,M,m) is a measure space.
    • For any set Ω\OmegaΩ, (Ω,P(Ω),μ)(\Omega, \mathcal{P}(\Omega),\mu)(Ω,P(Ω),μ) is a measure space, where μ(E)=No. of elements of E\mu(E)=\text{No. of elements of }Eμ(E)=No. of elements of E, the counting measure.
  • If E⊆RE \subseteq \mathbb{R}E⊆R, the “subspace” (E,MLeb∣E,m∣E)(E, \mathcal{M}_{Leb}|_{E},m|_{E})(E,MLeb​∣E​,m∣E​) is also a measurable space, where m∣Em|_{E}m∣E​ is the restriction of mmm to EEE, and MLeb∣E={F⊆E:F∈MLeb}={F∩E:F∈MLeb}\mathcal{M}_{Leb}|_{E}=\{ F \subseteq E:F \in \mathcal{M}_{Leb} \}=\{ F \cap E :F \in \mathcal{M}_{Leb}\}MLeb​∣E​={F⊆E:F∈MLeb​}={F∩E:F∈MLeb​}

Properties of General Measures

Big idea: general measures have the same properties that the Lebesgue measure has.

  • Monotonocity: if A,B∈F,A⊆BA,B \in \mathcal{F},A \subseteq BA,B∈F,A⊆B, then μ(A)≤μ(B)\mu(A) \le \mu(B)μ(A)≤μ(B).
  • Continuity: if A1⊆A2⊆…A_{1} \subseteq A_{2} \subseteq \dotsA1​⊆A2​⊆…, then μ(∪nAn)=lim⁡n→∞μ(An)\mu(\cup_{n}A_{n})=\lim_{ n \to \infty }\mu(A_{n})μ(∪n​An​)=limn→∞​μ(An​).

Proof similar to the result for the Lebesgue measure.

  • if A1⊇A2⊇…A_{1} \supseteq A_{2} \supseteq \dotsA1​⊇A2​⊇…, and μ(A1)<∞\mu(A_{1})< \inftyμ(A1​)<∞, then μ(∩n=0∞An)=lim⁡n→∞μ(An)\mu(\cap_{n=0}^{\infty}A_{n})=\lim_{ n \to \infty }\mu(A_{n})μ(∩n=0∞​An​)=limn→∞​μ(An​).

Proof: take their complements C1⊆C2⊆…C_{1}\subseteq C_{2} \subseteq\dotsC1​⊆C2​⊆…, and apply the previous result.

Generation and Borel Sets

  • An arbitrary intersection of σ\sigmaσ-fields is also a σ\sigmaσ-field.

Proof: just a routine check of the definition.

  • Given B⊆ΩB \subseteq \OmegaB⊆Ω, it generates a σ\sigmaσ-algebra FB\mathcal{F_{B}}FB​, the smallest σ\sigmaσ-algebra containing BBB. Equivalently, the σ\sigmaσ-algebra generated by BBB isFB=⋂{F⊂R:F is a σ-field containing B}\mathcal{F}_{B}=\bigcap\{\mathcal{F}\subset \mathbb{R}: \mathcal{F} \text{ is a }\sigma \text{-field containing }B \}FB​=⋂{F⊂R:F is a σ-field containing B}

  • Borel sets are members of the Borel σ\sigmaσ-algebra MBor\mathcal{M}_{Bor}MBor​, which is generated by the set of all intervals.

    • All open sets, being countable union of intervals, are Borel sets.
    • All countable sets, being countable union of singleton intervals [a,a][a,a][a,a], are Borel sets.

  • The same MBor\mathcal{M}_{Bor}MBor​ can be generated by any of the following families:

    • All intervals.
    • All finite open intervals (a,b)(a,b)(a,b).
    • All finite closed intervals [a,b][a,b][a,b].
    • All unbounded intervals (a,∞)(a, \infty)(a,∞).
    • Etc…

  • In particular, since all intervals are in M\mathcal{M}M, MBor⊂MLeb\mathcal{M}_{Bor} \subset \mathcal{M}_{Leb}MBor​⊂MLeb​. The inclusion is strict, and in particular some of the null sets are not in MBor\mathcal{M}_{Bor}MBor​.

Measurable Functions

  • On a measurable set E⊆RE \subseteq \mathbb{R}E⊆R, a function f:E→Rf: E \to \mathbb{R}f:E→R is (Lebesgue) measurable if any interval I⊆RI \subseteq \mathbb{R}I⊆R has a measurable preimage: f−1(I)={x∈E:f(x)∈I}∈MLebf^{-1}(I)=\{ x \in E: f(x) \in I \} \in \mathcal{M}_{Leb}f−1(I)={x∈E:f(x)∈I}∈MLeb​
  • More generally, in a measurable space (Ω,F)(\Omega, \mathcal{F})(Ω,F), a function fff is F\mathcal{F}F-measurable if any interval I⊆RI \subseteq \mathbb{R}I⊆R is in F\mathcal{F}F: f−1(I)={x∈Ω:f(x)∈I}∈Ff^{-1}(I)=\{ x \in \Omega:f(x) \in I \} \in \mathcal{F}f−1(I)={x∈Ω:f(x)∈I}∈F
  • A function fff being measurable is equivalent to one of the following families having measurable preimages:
    • ∀a:(a,∞)\forall a: (a,\infty)∀a:(a,∞)
    • ∀a:[a,∞)\forall a:[a,\infty)∀a:[a,∞)
    • ∀a:(−∞,a)\forall a:(-\infty,a)∀a:(−∞,a)
    • ∀a:(−∞,a]\forall a:(-\infty, a]∀a:(−∞,a]

Proof (for (a,∞)(a,\infty)(a,∞)):
(−∞,a](-\infty,a](−∞,a]: by taking complements f−1((−∞,a])=E∖f−1((a,∞))f^{-1}((-\infty,a])=E\setminus f^{-1}((a,\infty))f−1((−∞,a])=E∖f−1((a,∞)).
(−∞,a)(-\infty, a)(−∞,a): by countable union f−1((−∞,a))=∪nf−1((−∞,a−1/n])f^{-1}((-\infty, a))=\cup_{n}f^{-1}((-\infty,a-1 / n])f−1((−∞,a))=∪n​f−1((−∞,a−1/n])
[a,∞)[a,\infty)[a,∞): by taking complement of f−1((−∞,a))f^{-1}((-\infty, a))f−1((−∞,a))
(a,b)(a,b)(a,b): intersect f−1((−∞,b))∩f−1((a,∞))f^{-1}((-\infty, b)) \cap f^{-1}((a, \infty))f−1((−∞,b))∩f−1((a,∞))

  • Generally, f:Ω→Rf: \Omega \to \mathbb{R}f:Ω→R is F\mathcal{F}F-measurable if ∀G∈B:f−1(G)∈F\forall G \in B:f^{-1}(G) \in \mathcal{F}∀G∈B:f−1(G)∈F, where BBB generates the Borel set B\mathcal{B}B.

Proof: define the measurable preimages f∗(F)={G⊆R:f−1(G)∈F}f^{*}(\mathcal{F})=\{ G \subseteq \mathbb{R}:f^{-1}(G) \in \mathcal{F} \}f∗(F)={G⊆R:f−1(G)∈F}, which form a σ\sigmaσ-algebra in R\mathbb{R}R. Hence B⊆f∗(F)  ⟺  B⊆f∗(F)  ⟺  I∈f∗(F)B \subseteq f^{*}(\mathcal{F}) \iff \mathcal{B}\subseteq f^{*}(\mathcal{F}) \iff I \in f^{*}(\mathcal{F})B⊆f∗(F)⟺B⊆f∗(F)⟺I∈f∗(F) for all intervals III.

  • Constant functions and continuous functions are measurable.
  • Indicator functions of measurable sets are measurable.

Deriving Measurability

  • If fff is Lebesgue-mesurable, ggg is MBor\mathcal{M}_{Bor}MBor​-measurable, then g∘fg \circ fg∘f is Lebesgue measurable.

Proof: for any interval III, g−1(I)∈MBorg^{-1}(I) \in \mathcal{M}_{Bor}g−1(I)∈MBor​, so it is a countable union of intervals IiI_{i}Ii​. Then the preimage f−1(∪iIi)=∪if−1(Ii)∈MLebf^{-1}(\cup_{i}I_{i})=\cup_{i}f^{-1}(I_{i}) \in \mathcal{M}_{Leb}f−1(∪i​Ii​)=∪i​f−1(Ii​)∈MLeb​.

  • If f,gf,gf,g are measurable functions, their combination via a continuous function F:R×R→RF: \mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{R} \to \mathbb{R}F:R×R→R, given by h(x)=F(f(x),g(x))h(x)=F(f(x),g(x))h(x)=F(f(x),g(x)) is also measurable.
    • In particular, sums and products of measurable functions are also measurable.

Lebesgue Integration - Introduction

Simple Functions

  • A simple function ϕ:R→R\phi: \mathbb{R} \to \mathbb{R}ϕ:R→R is a measurable function with a finite image: ϕ(R)={a1,…,an} finite,ϕ−1(ai)={x∈R:ϕ(x)=ai}≡Ai∈MLeb.\begin{align*} \phi(\mathbb{R})&=\{ a_{1},\dots,a_{n} \} \text{ finite,}\\ \phi^{-1}(a_{i})&=\{ x \in \mathbb{R}:\phi(x)=a_{i} \} \equiv A_{i} \in \mathcal{M}_{Leb}. \end{align*}ϕ(R)ϕ−1(ai​)​={a1​,…,an​} finite,={x∈R:ϕ(x)=ai​}≡Ai​∈MLeb​.​so in its canonical/standard form, ϕ=∑iai1Ai\phi=\sum_{i}a_{i}\mathbb{1}_{A_{i}}ϕ=∑i​ai​1Ai​​ (assuming aia_{i}ai​ are all distinct).

  • If f:R→[0,∞]f:\mathbb{R} \to [0,\infty]f:R→[0,∞] is a non-negative measurable function, then it is the limit of some increasing sequence of simple functions: ∃(ϕn) simple:ϕn↗f\exists (\phi_{n})\text{ simple}:\phi_{n} \nearrow f∃(ϕn​) simple:ϕn​↗f

Proof: define ϕn\phi_{n}ϕn​ to be fff rounded down to the nearest 2−n2^{-n}2−n, capped at 2n2^{n}2n.
To do so, split [0,2n)[0,2^n)[0,2n) in the image equally into 4n4^{n}4n intervals, namely {[0,2−n)+k2−n:k=0,…,4n−1}\{[0,2^{-n})+k2^{-n}: k =0,\dots,4^{n}-1 \}{[0,2−n)+k2−n:k=0,…,4n−1}Then for each interval, take its preimage: Bk,n=f−1([0,2−n)+k2−n)B_{k,n}=f^{-1}\left([0,2^{-n})+k 2^{-n}\right)Bk,n​=f−1([0,2−n)+k2−n)and define ϕn\phi_{n}ϕn​ to be k2−nk2^{-n}k2−n on this set. Otherwise, ϕn=2n\phi_{n}=2^{n}ϕn​=2n.
Then for points x:f(x)<∞x:f(x)<\inftyx:f(x)<∞, f−ϕn<2−n→0f-\phi_{n}<2^{-n} \to 0f−ϕn​<2−n→0. For points x:f(x)=∞x: f(x)=\inftyx:f(x)=∞, ϕn=2n→f(x)\phi_{n}=2^{n} \to f(x)ϕn​=2n→f(x).

Lebesgue Integral of Non-Negative Functions

  • The (Lebesgue) integral of a simple function ϕ=∑iai1Ai\phi=\sum_{i}a_{i}\mathbb{1}_{A_{i}}ϕ=∑i​ai​1Ai​​ is ∫ϕ=∑iai m(Ai)\int \phi = \sum_{i}a_{i}\,m(A_{i})∫ϕ=i∑​ai​m(Ai​)with the convention that if ai=0, m(Ai)=∞a_{i}=0,\,m(A_{i})=\inftyai​=0,m(Ai​)=∞, their product is 000.

    • Any indicator of null sets have integral 000, for example the rationals in [0,1][0,1][0,1]: ∫[0,1]1Q dm=m(Q∩[0,1])=0\int _{[0,1]} \mathbb{1_{Q}} \, dm=m(\mathbb{Q}\cap[0,1])=0∫[0,1]​1Q​dm=m(Q∩[0,1])=0.

  • The (Lebesgue) integral of a non-negative function fff is defined to be: ∫f=sup⁡{∫ϕ:0≤ϕ≤f,  ϕ simple}\int f = \sup \left\{ \int \phi : 0 \le \phi \le f,\,\,\phi \text{ simple} \right\}∫f=sup{∫ϕ:0≤ϕ≤f,ϕ simple}and equivalently denoted ∫f dm\int f \, dm∫fdm to make the measure explicit.

  • The integral of fff over a measurable set E⊆RE \subseteq \mathbb{R}E⊆R is defined to be ∫Ef≡∫f⋅χE\int _{E} f \equiv \int f \cdot \chi_{E}∫E​f≡∫f⋅χE​

Properties of the Integral (Simple Functions)

Big idea: the integral of simple functions have the expected properties. These will carry over to general non-negative functions.

  • Let ϕ,ψ\phi, \psiϕ,ψ be simple functions, and D,E∈MD,E \in \mathcal{M}D,E∈M, a∈Ra \in \mathbb{R}a∈R, then their integrals are:
    • Order-preserving: 0≤ϕ≤ψ⟹∫ϕ≤∫ψ0 \le \phi \le \psi \Longrightarrow \int \phi \le \int \psi0≤ϕ≤ψ⟹∫ϕ≤∫ψ.
    • Set-additive: D∩E=∅⟹∫D∪Eϕ=∫Dϕ+∫EϕD \cap E=\emptyset \Longrightarrow \int_{D \cup E} \phi=\int _{D} \phi + \int _{E} \phiD∩E=∅⟹∫D∪E​ϕ=∫D​ϕ+∫E​ϕ.
    • Linear: ∫(ϕ+ψ)=∫ϕ+∫ψ\int (\phi+\psi)=\int \phi+\int \psi∫(ϕ+ψ)=∫ϕ+∫ψ, and ∫aϕ=a∫ϕ\int a\phi=a\int\phi∫aϕ=a∫ϕ.

Proof:
Order: Y(D,ϕ)⊆Y(D,ψ)Y(D, \phi) \subseteq Y(D, \psi)Y(D,ϕ)⊆Y(D,ψ), so their suprema follow the inequality.
Additivity: write ϕ=∑iai1Ai\phi=\sum_{i}a_{i}\mathbb{1}_{A_{i}}ϕ=∑i​ai​1Ai​​ as in the definition, then use the countable additivity of the measure in its integral: ∫D∪Eϕ dm=∑iai m(Ai∩(D∪E))=∑iai m((Ai∩D)∪(Ai∩E))=∑iai m(Ai∩D)+∑iai m(Ai∩E)=∫Dϕ dm+∫Eϕ dm\begin{align*} \int _{D \cup E} \phi \, dm&=\sum_{i} a_{i}\,m(A_{i} \cap (D \cup E))\\ &= \sum_{i} a_{i}\,m\left((A_{i}\cap D) \cup (A_{i} \cap E)\right) \\ &= \sum_{i} a_{i}\,m(A_{i} \cap D) + \sum_{i} a_{i}\,m(A_{i} \cap E)\\ &= \int _{D} \phi \, dm + \int _{E} \phi \, dm \end{align*}∫D∪E​ϕdm​=i∑​ai​m(Ai​∩(D∪E))=i∑​ai​m((Ai​∩D)∪(Ai​∩E))=i∑​ai​m(Ai​∩D)+i∑​ai​m(Ai​∩E)=∫D​ϕdm+∫E​ϕdm​
Linearity: just grinding set notations.

Monotone Convergence Theorem

Big idea: the MCT allows swapping the integral and the limit. Hence properties of increasing simple functions (ϕn)(\phi_{n})(ϕn​) carry over to their limit fff.

  • The monotone convergence theorem (MCT) states that if (fn)(f_{n})(fn​) are non-negative, measurable functions, and (fn)↗f(f_{n}) \nearrow f(fn​)↗f, then lim⁡n→∞∫fn=∫lim⁡n→∞fn=∫f\lim_{ n \to \infty } \int f_{n} = \int \lim_{ n \to \infty } f_{n} = \int f n→∞lim​∫fn​=∫n→∞lim​fn​=∫f

Proof: (≤\le≤) is immediate from monotonocity as fn≤f⇒∫fn≤∫ff_{n} \le f \Rightarrow \int f_{n} \le \int ffn​≤f⇒∫fn​≤∫f.
(≥\ge≥): take any simple function ϕ:0≤ϕ≤f\phi:0 \le \phi \le fϕ:0≤ϕ≤f, and it’s sufficient to show that lim⁡n→∞∫fn dm≥∫ϕ dm\lim_{ n \to \infty }\int f_{n} \, dm \ge \int \phi \, dmlimn→∞​∫fn​dm≥∫ϕdm.
Scale down ϕ\phiϕ by any α∈(0,1)\alpha \in (0,1)α∈(0,1) to get αϕ\alpha \phiαϕ, and define Bn≡{x:fn≥αϕ(x)}B_{n} \equiv \{ x: f_{n} \ge \alpha \phi(x) \}Bn​≡{x:fn​≥αϕ(x)}so that BnB_{n}Bn​ is increasing, with B=∪nBn=RB=\cup_{n} B_{n} = \mathbb{R}B=∪n​Bn​=R. Then ∫Rfn≥∫Bnfn≥α∫Bnϕ\int _{\mathbb{R}} f_{n} \ge \int_{B_{n}} f_{n} \ge \alpha\int _{B_{n}} \phi ∫R​fn​≥∫Bn​​fn​≥α∫Bn​​ϕLetting n→∞n \to \inftyn→∞, lim⁡n→∞∫Rfn dx≥lim⁡n→∞α∫Bnϕ=α∫Rϕ d\lim_{ n \to \infty } \int _{\mathbb{R}}f_{n} \, dx \ge \lim_{ n \to \infty }\alpha\int _{B_{n}} \phi= \alpha\int _{\mathbb{R}} \phi\, dn→∞lim​∫R​fn​dx≥n→∞lim​α∫Bn​​ϕ=α∫R​ϕdwhere convergence in RHS\mathrm{RHS}RHS can be shown with the standard form of simple functions, and that m(Bn∩E)→m(R∩E)m(B_{n} \cap E) \to m(\mathbb{R} \cap E)m(Bn​∩E)→m(R∩E) when BnB_{n}Bn​ increases to R\mathbb{R}R.
Then taking the limit as α↗1\alpha \nearrow 1α↗1 gives the result.

  • The baby MCT states that if (En)⊆M(E_{n}) \subseteq \mathcal{M}(En​)⊆M is an increasing sequence, and E=∪nEnE=\cup_{n}E_{n}E=∪n​En​, f≥0f \ge 0f≥0 is measurable, then ∫Ef=sup⁡n∫Enf=lim⁡n→∞∫Enf\int _{E} f = \sup_{n} \int_{E_{n}} f = \lim_{ n \to \infty } \int _{E_{n}}f ∫E​f=nsup​∫En​​f=n→∞lim​∫En​​fwhich is just the special case of the MCT on (f⋅χEn)↗f(f\cdot \chi_{E_{n}})\nearrow f(f⋅χEn​​)↗f.

    • It’s known by this name only at Oxford.

  • MCT for series: for a sequence (fn)≥0  a.e.(f_{n}) \ge 0\,\,\mathrm{a.e.}(fn​)≥0a.e., ∫∑n=0∞fn=∑n=0∞∫fn\int \sum_{n=0}^{\infty} f_{n} = \sum_{n=0}^{\infty}\int f_{n}∫n=0∑∞​fn​=n=0∑∞​∫fn​which is the MCT applied to ∑n=0kfn↗∑n=0∞fn\sum_{n=0}^{k} f_{n} \nearrow \sum_{n=0}^{\infty} f_{n}∑n=0k​fn​↗∑n=0∞​fn​.

Properties of the Integral (Non-Negative Functions)

Big idea: since non-negative functions is the limit of some increasing sequence of simple functions, many properties carry over via the MCT.

  • If fff is non-negative and measurable, then there is a sequence of increasing simple functions (ϕn)↗f(\phi_{n}) \nearrow f(ϕn​)↗f, so by the MCT, ∫f dm=lim⁡n→∞∫ϕn\int f \, dm = \lim_{ n \to \infty } \int \phi_{n}∫fdm=n→∞lim​∫ϕn​
  • Additivity: if f,g≥0f,g \ge 0f,g≥0 are measurable, then ∫(f+g) dm=∫f dm+∫g dm\int (f+g) \, dm = \int f \, dm + \int g \, dm∫(f+g)dm=∫fdm+∫gdm

Proof: approximate f,gf,gf,g with (ϕn)↗f(\phi_{n})\nearrow f(ϕn​)↗f, and (ψn)↗g(\psi_{n}) \nearrow g(ψn​)↗g. Then (ϕn+ψn)↗(f+g)(\phi_{n}+\psi_{n}) \nearrow (f+g)(ϕn​+ψn​)↗(f+g), so ∫(f+g) dx=MCTlim⁡n→∞∫(ϕn+ψn)=   lim⁡n→∞(∫ϕn+∫ψn)=MCT∫f+∫g\begin{align*} \int (f+g) \, dx \overset{\mathrm{MCT}}{=} &\lim_{ n \to \infty } \int (\phi_{n} + \psi_{n}) \\ =\,\,\, &\lim_{ n \to \infty } \left( \int \phi_{n} +\int \psi_{n} \right)\\ \overset{\mathrm{ MCT}}{=} &\int f + \int g \end{align*}∫(f+g)dx=MCT==MCT​n→∞lim​∫(ϕn​+ψn​)n→∞lim​(∫ϕn​+∫ψn​)∫f+∫g​

  • Null sets are negligible: if a measurable function f≥0f \ge 0f≥0, then ∫f=0  ⟺  f=0  a.e.\int f=0 \iff f=0\,\, \mathrm{a.e.} ∫f=0⟺f=0a.e.and hence g=h  a.e.  ⟺  ∫g=∫h dxg=h\,\,\mathrm{a.e.}\iff \int g =\int h \, dxg=ha.e.⟺∫g=∫hdx for f,g≥0f,g \ge0f,g≥0.

Proof: find non-negative simple functions (ϕn)↗f(\phi_{n}) \nearrow f(ϕn​)↗f.
(⇐\Leftarrow⇐) is trivial: any simple function ϕ:0≤ϕ≤f\phi:0\le\phi \le fϕ:0≤ϕ≤f mush be 0  a.e.0\,\,\mathrm{a.e.}0a.e.
(⇒\Rightarrow⇒) consider En={x:f(x)>1/n}E_{n}=\{ x:f(x)>1 / n \}En​={x:f(x)>1/n}, and we want to show that ∪nEn={x:f(x)>0}≡E\cup_{n}E_{n}=\{ x: f(x)>0\}\equiv E∪n​En​={x:f(x)>0}≡E is null.
It’s then enough to show that EnE_{n}En​ is null for all nnn. But if for contradiction m(En)>0m(E_{n})>0m(En​)>0, then 1nχEn≤f\frac{1}{n}\chi_{E_{n}} \le fn1​χEn​​≤f has integral 0<m(En)n=∫1nχEn≤∫f=00<\frac{m(E_{n})}{n}=\int \frac{1}{n}\chi_{E_{n}} \le \int f =0 0<nm(En​)​=∫n1​χEn​​≤∫f=0a contradiction.
(g=hg=hg=h): take f=g−hf=g-hf=g−h and apply the above.

  • On the interval [a,b][a,b][a,b], for function f∈C[a,b]f \in C[a,b]f∈C[a,b], its Riemann and Lebesgue integrals are the same.

Proof: let (ϕn)(\phi_{n})(ϕn​) by the optimal minorant step functions obtained by bisecting [a,b][a,b][a,b] nnn times, then (ϕn)↗f(\phi_{n}) \nearrow f(ϕn​)↗f.
Their integrals converge to the Riemann integral by definition, and to the Lebesgue integral by the MCT.

Lebesgue Integration - General Functions

Definitions

  • The positive and negative parts of a function fff are: f+≡max⁡(f,0),  f−≡max⁡(−f,0)f^{+}\equiv \max(f,0),\,\,f^{-}\equiv \max(-f,0)f+≡max(f,0),f−≡max(−f,0)and note that f=f+−f−f=f^{+}-f^{-}f=f+−f−, and ∣f∣=f++f−|f|=f^{+}+f^{-}∣f∣=f++f−.
  • A measuable function fff is integrable if both its positive and negative parts have a finite integral: ∫Ef± dm∈(−∞,∞)\int _{E} f^{\pm} \, dm \in (-\infty,\infty)∫E​f±dm∈(−∞,∞); in that case its integral is ∫f≡∫f+−∫f−\int f \equiv \int f^{+} -\int f^{-} ∫f≡∫f+−∫f−
  • Over a set E∈MLebE \in \mathcal{M}_{Leb}E∈MLeb​, a measurable function fff is integrable if f⋅χEf\cdot\chi_{E}f⋅χE​ is. The set of integrable functions is denoted L1(E)\mathcal{L}^{1}(E)L1(E).

Properties of the Integral (General Functions)

Big idea: most property carry over to general functions fff via their positive/negative parts f±f^{\pm}f±.

  • Integrals are linear to addition: ∫(f+g) dm=∫f dm+∫g dm\int (f+g) \, dm=\int f \, dm + \int g \, dm∫(f+g)dm=∫fdm+∫gdm.

Proof: note that (f+g)=(f+g)+−(f+g)−=f+−f−+g+−g−\begin{align*} (f+g)&= (f+g)^{+}-(f+g)^{-}\\ &= f^{+}-f^{-}+g^{+}-g^{-} \end{align*}(f+g)​=(f+g)+−(f+g)−=f+−f−+g+−g−​so rearrange to get (f+g)++f−+g−=(f+g)−+f++g+(f+g)^{+}+f^{-}+g^{-}=(f+g)^{-}+f^{+}+g^{+}(f+g)++f−+g−=(f+g)−+f++g+, all of which are non-negative functions, and apply the linearity property on integrals of non-negative functions.

  • Integrals are linear to scaling: for any c∈R,f∈L1(A)c \in \mathbb{R}, f \in \mathcal{L}^{1}(A)c∈R,f∈L1(A), ∫A(cf) dx=c∫Af dx\int _{A} (cf) \, dx=c\int _{A} f \, dx∫A​(cf)dx=c∫A​fdx

Proof: approximate both sides with simple functions, for which the identity is trivial.

  • Integrals preserve orders: if f≤gf \le gf≤g, then ∫f dm≤∫g dm\int f \, dm \le \int g \, dm∫fdm≤∫gdm.

Proof: if f≤gf \le gf≤g, then f+≤g+f^{+} \le g^{+}f+≤g+, and f−≥g−f^{-} \ge g^{-}f−≥g−. Then apply the result for non-negative functions to their integrals.

  • Bounds on the integrand: if fff is integrable, then

    • ∣f∣≠∞  a.e.|f| \ne \infty\,\,\mathrm{a.e.}∣f∣=∞a.e.;
    • If ∫∣f∣=0\int |f| =0∫∣f∣=0, then f=0  a.e.f=0\,\,\mathrm{a.e.}f=0a.e.

  • Bounds on the integral: if fff is integrable, then

    • ∣∫f∣≤∫∣f∣|\int f |\le \int |f|∣∫f∣≤∫∣f∣.
    • Over a measurable set AAA, m(A)inf⁡x∈Af≤∫Af dm≤m(A)sup⁡x∈Afm(A)\inf _{x \in A} f \le \int _{A} f\, dm \le m(A)\sup _{x \in A} fm(A)x∈Ainf​f≤∫A​fdm≤m(A)x∈Asup​f

Hint for the first property: write fff and ∣f∣|f|∣f∣ in terms of f±f^{\pm}f±.

Deducing Integrability

  • Absolute values: if fff is integrable, so is ∣f∣|f|∣f∣; the converse is true if fff is measurable.
    • The extra condition to the converse is just because ∣f∣|f|∣f∣ integrable ⇏f\not \Rightarrow f⇒f integrable.

Proof/Hint: again, write fff and ∣f∣|f|∣f∣ in terms of f±f^{\pm}f±, then use linearity.

  • The Comparison Test: if f,gf,gf,g are measurable,
    • ∣f∣≤g|f| \le g∣f∣≤g, ggg integrable, then fff is also integrable;
    • ∣f∣≥g≥0|f| \ge g \ge 0∣f∣≥g≥0, ggg not integrable, then neither is fff.

Proof/Hint: use the order-preserving property to find ∣f∣|f|∣f∣ integrable/not integrable, then use the previous result.

  • Products: if fff is integrable, g:∣g∣≤cg:|g| \le cg:∣g∣≤c is measurable and bounded, then f⋅gf \cdot gf⋅g is integrable.

Proof: fgfgfg is measurable, and ∣fg∣≤c∣f∣|fg| \le c|f|∣fg∣≤c∣f∣, so the Comparison Test gives integrability.

  • Changing on a null set: if measurable functions f=g  a.e.f=g \,\,\mathrm{a.e.}f=ga.e., then fff integrable   ⟺  g\iff g⟺g integrable, and if they are, ∫f=∫g\int f = \int g∫f=∫g.

Proof: f±=g±  a.e.f^{\pm}=g^{\pm}\,\,\mathrm{a.e.}f±=g±a.e., so ∫f±=∫g±\int f^{\pm} =\int g^{\pm}∫f±=∫g± by the result for non-negative functions.
WLOG assume fff integrable, then ∫g±=∫f±<∞\int g^{\pm}=\int f^{\pm} <\infty∫g±=∫f±<∞, ggg is integrable, and their integrals are the same.

Lebesgue and Riemann Integrals

  • Any Riemann-integrable function f:[a,b]→Rf: [a,b] \to \mathbb{R}f:[a,b]→R is Lebesgue-integrable.

Proof: if fff is Riemann-integrable on [a,b][a,b][a,b], it is bounded. So it remains to show that fff is measurable.
Since fff is integrable, take a sequence of minorants (ϕn)↗f(\phi_{n}) \nearrow f(ϕn​)↗f and majorants (ψn)↘f(\psi_{n})\searrow f(ψn​)↘f. Let g=sup⁡n(ϕn)g=\sup_{n}(\phi_{n})g=supn​(ϕn​) and h=inf⁡n(ψn)h=\inf_{n}(\psi_{n})h=infn​(ψn​) be their pointwise limits, and g,hg,hg,h are measurable since ϕn,ψn\phi_{n},\psi_{n}ϕn​,ψn​ are.
Then g≤f≤hg \le f \le hg≤f≤h, and 0≤h−g≤ψn−ϕn0 \le h-g \le \psi_{n}-\phi_{n}0≤h−g≤ψn​−ϕn​, so 0≤∫[a,b](h−g)≤∫[a,b](ψn−ϕn)→00 \le\int_{[a,b]} (h-g) \le \int _{[a,b]} (\psi_{n}-\phi_{n}) \to 0 0≤∫[a,b]​(h−g)≤∫[a,b]​(ψn​−ϕn​)→0hence h=g  a.e.h=g\,\,\mathrm{a.e.}h=ga.e., and so f=g  a.e.f=g\,\,\mathrm{a.e.}f=ga.e., and ggg measurable implies fff measurable.

  • Furthermore, in that case Lebesgue and Riemann integrals agree: ↑‾∫[a,b]fLebesgue=↑‾∫abf dxRiemann\underset{\text{Lebesgue}}{\vphantom{\underline{\Bigg\uparrow}}\int _{[a,b]} f }=\underset{\text{Riemann}}{\vphantom{\underline{\Bigg\uparrow}}\int _{a}^{b}f \, dx}Lebesgue⏐↑​​∫[a,b]​f​=Riemann⏐↑​​∫ab​fdx​

Proof: obviously Riemann and Lebesgue integrals agree for step functions.
Denote I(S)={∫abϕ∣ϕ∈S}I(S)=\left\{ \int_{a}^{b} \phi | \phi \in S \right\}I(S)={∫ab​ϕ∣ϕ∈S}, then ↑‾∫abf dxRiemann=sup⁡I(minorants)≤↑‾∫[a,b]fLebesgue≤inf⁡I(majorants)=↑‾∫abf dxRiemann\underset{\text{Riemann}}{\vphantom{\underline{\Bigg\uparrow}}\int _{a}^{b}f \, dx} = \sup I(\mathrm{minorants}) \le \underset{\text{Lebesgue}}{\vphantom{\underline{\Bigg\uparrow}}\int _{[a,b]} f } \le \inf I(\mathrm{majorants}) = \underset{\text{Riemann}}{\vphantom{\underline{\Bigg\uparrow}}\int _{a}^{b}f \, dx}Riemann⏐↑​​∫ab​fdx​=supI(minorants)≤Lebesgue⏐↑​​∫[a,b]​f​≤infI(majorants)=Riemann⏐↑​​∫ab​fdx​where the inequalities are justified by the integral preserving the orders in minorant≤f≤majorant\text{minorant}\le f \le \text{majorant}minorant≤f≤majorant.

  • If the improper Riemann integral of f≥0f \ge 0f≥0 exists, so does the Lebesgue integral, and they are equal: lim⁡a,b→∞∫−abf dx≡∫−∞∞f dx=∫Rf\lim_{ a,b \to \infty }\int _{-a}^{b}f \, dx \equiv \int _{-\infty}^{\infty}f \, dx=\int _{\mathbb{R}} f a,b→∞lim​∫−ab​fdx≡∫−∞∞​fdx=∫R​f
    • f≥0f \ge 0f≥0 is necessary: otherwise the positive and negative components of fff can have unbounded integrals (hence Lebesgue non-integrable) that cancel out (giving finite Riemann integral). E.g. sin⁡(x)/x\sin(x) / xsin(x)/x over R\mathbb{R}R.

Proof: fn≡f1[−n,n]↗ff_{n}\equiv f \mathbb{1}_{[-n,n]}\nearrow ffn​≡f1[−n,n]​↗f is Riemann (hence Lebesgue) integrable, so apply the previous result for finite intervals to get ∫−nnf dx=∫[−n,n]f\int _{-n}^{n}f \, dx =\int _{[-n,n]} f ∫−nn​fdx=∫[−n,n]​fthen LHS→∫−∞∞f dx\mathrm{LHS} \to \int _{-\infty}^{\infty}f \, dxLHS→∫−∞∞​fdx, and by the baby MCT, RHS→∫Rf dx\mathrm{RHS} \to\int _{\mathbb{R}} f \, dxRHS→∫R​fdx; hence these are equal.

Dominated Convergence Theorem

The DCT

  • Fatou’s Lemma states that if (fn)(f_{n})(fn​) is a sequence of non-negative measurable functions, then ∫lim inf⁡n→∞fn≤lim inf⁡n→∞∫fn\int \liminf_{ n \to \infty } f_{n} \le \liminf_{ n \to \infty } \int f_{n} ∫n→∞liminf​fn​≤n→∞liminf​∫fn​

Proof: denote gk=inf⁡n≥kfng_{k}=\inf_{n \ge k}f_{n}gk​=infn≥k​fn​, then (1) gn↗lim inf⁡n→∞fn(1)\,g_{n}\nearrow\liminf_{n \to \infty}f_{n}(1)gn​↗liminfn→∞​fn​, and (2) gn≤fn(2)\, g_{n} \le f_{n}(2)gn​≤fn​,
Hence ∫lim inf⁡n→∞fn =MCT+(1)lim⁡n→∞∫gn=lim inf⁡n→∞∫gn≤(2)lim inf⁡n→∞∫fn\int \liminf_{ n \to \infty }f_{n} \, \overset{\mathrm{MCT}+(1)}{=} \lim_{ n \to \infty } \int g_{n} = \liminf_{ n \to \infty } \int g_{n} \overset{(2)}{\le} \liminf_{ n \to \infty } \int f_{n} ∫n→∞liminf​fn​=MCT+(1)n→∞lim​∫gn​=n→∞liminf​∫gn​≤(2)​n→∞liminf​∫fn​

  • The Dominated Convergence Theorem (DCT) states that for a sequence of integrable functions (fn)(f_{n})(fn​), if:
    • (fn)→f  a.e.(f_{n}) \to f\,\,\mathrm{a.e.}(fn​)→fa.e.,
    • and ∃g\exists g∃g integrable, such that ∀n≥1:∣fn∣≤g  a.e.\forall n \ge 1:|f_{n}| \le g \,\,\mathrm{a.e.}∀n≥1:∣fn​∣≤ga.e.,
  • Then the limit fff is integrable, and ∫f=lim⁡n→∞∫fn\int f =\lim_{ n \to \infty }\int f_{n}∫f=limn→∞​∫fn​.
    • That is, if a sequence is dominated by an integrable function, then the integral of its limit equals the limit of its integrals.

Proof: fff is measurable as the a.e.\mathrm{a.e.}a.e. limit of measurable functions.
The Comparison Test with g≥∣f∣  a.e.g \ge |f|\,\, \mathrm{a.e.}g≥∣f∣a.e. gives integrability of ∣f∣|f|∣f∣, hence fff.
Consider (g−fn)(g-f_{n})(g−fn​) and (g+fn)(g+f_{n})(g+fn​), both non-negative and measurable.
Apply Fatou’s Lemma to each to get the inequalities in (1)∫(g−f)=∫lim inf⁡n→∞(g−fn)≤lim inf⁡n→∞∫(g−fn)=∫g−lim sup⁡n→∞∫fn(2)∫(g+f)=∫lim inf⁡n→∞(g+fn)≤lim inf⁡n→∞∫(g+fn)=∫g+lim inf⁡n→∞∫fn\begin{align*} (1) &\int (g-f) = \int \liminf_{ n \to \infty } (g-f_{n}) \le \liminf_{ n \to \infty } \int (g-f_{n}) = \int g - \limsup_{ n \to \infty } \int f_{n}\\ (2) &\int (g+f) = \int \liminf_{ n \to \infty } (g+f_{n}) \le \liminf_{ n \to \infty } \int (g+f_{n}) = \int g + \liminf_{ n \to \infty } \int f_{n} \end{align*}(1)(2)​∫(g−f)=∫n→∞liminf​(g−fn​)≤n→∞liminf​∫(g−fn​)=∫g−n→∞limsup​∫fn​∫(g+f)=∫n→∞liminf​(g+fn​)≤n→∞liminf​∫(g+fn​)=∫g+n→∞liminf​∫fn​​Hence lim sup⁡n→∞∫fn≤(1)∫f ≤(2)lim inf⁡n→∞∫fn\limsup_{ n \to \infty } \int f_{n} \overset{(1)}{\le} \int f\, \overset{(2)}{\le} \liminf_{ n \to \infty } \int f_{n}n→∞limsup​∫fn​≤(1)​∫f≤(2)​n→∞liminf​∫fn​which is only possible if they are all equal (and hence equal to lim⁡n→∞∫fn\lim_{ n \to \infty } \int f_{n}limn→∞​∫fn​).

Derivatives of the DCT

  • The Bounded Convergence Theorem (BCT): on a bounded interval III, if (fn)⊆L1(I)(f_{n}) \subseteq \mathcal{L}^{1}(I)(fn​)⊆L1(I) is bounded by some constant ccc almost everywhere, and (fn)→f  a.e.(f_{n}) \to f\,\,\mathrm{a.e.}(fn​)→fa.e.; then f∈L1(I)f \in \mathcal{L}^{1}(I)f∈L1(I), and ∫f=lim⁡n→∞∫fn\int f =\lim_{ n \to \infty }\int f_{n}∫f=limn→∞​∫fn​.

Proof: constants are integrable on bounded intervals, so this is just the special case of the DCT where g≡cg \equiv cg≡c.

  • Beppo-Levi Theorem states that if (gn)(g_{n})(gn​) are integrable, ∑n∫∣gn∣<∞\sum_{n} \int |g_{n}| < \infty∑n​∫∣gn​∣<∞, then ∑ng\sum_{n} g∑n​g converges a.e.\mathrm{a.e.}a.e. to an integrable limit, and ∫∑n=0∞gn=∑n=0∞∫gn\int \sum_{n=0}^{\infty} g_{n} = \sum_{n=0}^{\infty} \int g_{n}∫n=0∑∞​gn​=n=0∑∞​∫gn​

Proof:
Convergence: define γ(x)=∑n∣gn(x)∣\gamma(x)=\sum_{n}|g_{n}(x)|γ(x)=∑n​∣gn​(x)∣, a monotone series of non-negative, measurable functions, so the MCT of series gives ∫γ=lim⁡k→∞∑n=0k∫∣gn∣<∞\int \gamma =\lim_{ k \to \infty }\sum_{n=0}^{k}\int |g_{n}| < \infty ∫γ=k→∞lim​n=0∑k​∫∣gn​∣<∞so γ\gammaγ is integrable, hence finite a.e.\mathrm{a.e.}a.e.. So the series ∑ngn\sum_{n}g_{n}∑n​gn​ converges absolutely a.e.\mathrm{a.e.}a.e..

Integral: since partial sums ∑n=0kgn\sum_{n=0}^{k}g_{n}∑n=0k​gn​ converge and are dominated by the integrable function γ\gammaγ, the DCT guarantees ∑ngn\sum_{n} g_{n}∑n​gn​ to be integrable, and: ∫∑n=0∞gn=∫lim⁡k→∞∑n=0kgn=DCTlim⁡k→∞∫∑n=0kgn=lim⁡k→∞∑n=0k∫gn=∑n=0∞∫gn\int \sum_{n=0}^{\infty} g_{n} =\int \lim_{ k \to \infty } \sum_{n=0}^{k} g_{n}\overset{\mathrm{DCT}}{=} \lim_{ k \to \infty } \int \sum_{n=0}^{k}g_{n} = \lim_{ k \to \infty } \sum_{n=0}^{k} \int g_{n}=\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}\int g_{n}∫n=0∑∞​gn​=∫k→∞lim​n=0∑k​gn​=DCTk→∞lim​∫n=0∑k​gn​=k→∞lim​n=0∑k​∫gn​=n=0∑∞​∫gn​

DCT of Integrals with a Parameter

  • This section focuses on the integrals of the form F(y)=∫f(x,y) dxF(y)=\int f(x,y) \, dx F(y)=∫f(x,y)dxand their differentiability and continuity.

  • The continuous parameter DCT states that for a function f:I×J→Rf:I \times J \to \mathbb{R}f:I×J→R, where I,JI,JI,J are intervals, then the function F(y)=∫If(x,y) dxF(y)=\int _{I}f(x,y) \, dxF(y)=∫I​f(x,y)dx is continuous over JJJ if:

    • (1)(1)(1) integrability: fixing any yyy, x↦f(x,y)x \mapsto f(x,y)x↦f(x,y) is integrable over III.
    • (2)(2)(2) continuity: fixing any y0y_{0}y0​ and for almost all xxx, mapping y↦f(x,y)y \mapsto f(x,y)y↦f(x,y) is continuous at y0y_{0}y0​.
    • (3)(3)(3) domination: ∃g∈L1(I)\exists g \in \mathcal{L}^{1}(I)∃g∈L1(I) such that: fixing any yyy, then ∣f(x,y)∣≤g(x)|f(x,y)|\le g(x)∣f(x,y)∣≤g(x) for almost all xxx.

Proof: fix any yyy, and we shall show that for any (yn)→y(y_{n}) \to y(yn​)→y, there is F(yn)→F(y)F(y_{n})\to F(y)F(yn​)→F(y).
Define fn(x)=f(x,yn)f_{n}(x)=f(x,y_{n})fn​(x)=f(x,yn​), where ∣fn(x)∣≤g(x)  a.e.|f_{n}(x)|\le g(x)\,\,\mathrm{a.e.}∣fn​(x)∣≤g(x)a.e. by condition (3)(3)(3). By (2)(2)(2), fn(x)→f(x,y)f_{n}(x) \to f(x,y)fn​(x)→f(x,y) for almost all xxx. Then the (single-variable) DCT applies, giving F(yn)=∫fn(x) dx→∫f dx=F(y)F(y_{n})=\int f_{n}(x) \, dx \to \int f \, dx=F(y) F(yn​)=∫fn​(x)dx→∫fdx=F(y)and hence FFF is continuous at any yyy.

  • Differentiability: with f:I×J→Rf:I \times J \to \mathbb{R}f:I×J→R, its integral F(y)=∫If(x,y) dxF(y)=\int _{I}f(x,y) \, dxF(y)=∫I​f(x,y)dx is differentiable with F′(y)=∫Ify dxF'(y)=\int _{I}f_{y} \, dxF′(y)=∫I​fy​dx if:
    • (1)(1)(1) integrability: fixing any yyy, x↦f(x,y)x \mapsto f(x,y)x↦f(x,y) is integrable over III.
    • (2)(2)(2) differentiability: for almost all xxx, fyf_{y}fy​ exists for all yyy.
    • (3)(3)(3) domination: ∃h(x)∈L1(I)\exists h(x) \in \mathcal{L}^{1}(I)∃h(x)∈L1(I) such that for almost all xxx, ∣fy(x,y)∣≤h(x)|f_{y}(x,y)|\le h(x)∣fy​(x,y)∣≤h(x) for ∀y\forall y∀y.

Proof: we shall show that FFF is differentiable at an arbitrary yyy. Find any sequence (yn)→y(y_{n}) \to y(yn​)→y with yn≠0y_{n} \ne 0yn​=0, lim⁡n→∞F(yn)−F(y)yn−y=lim⁡n→∞∫If(x,yn)−f(x,y)yn−y dx=∫Ilim⁡n→∞f(yn)−f(y)yn−y dx(3), DCT=∫Ify(x,y) dx(2)\begin{align*} \lim_{ n \to \infty } \frac{F(y_{n})-F(y)}{y_{n}-y}&=\lim_{ n \to \infty } \int_{I} \frac{f(x,y_{n})-f(x,y)}{y_{n}-y} \,dx\\ &= \int _{I} \lim_{ n \to \infty } \frac{f(y_{n})-f(y)}{y_{n}-y} \,dx && (3),\,\text{DCT}\\ &= \int _{I} f_{y}(x,y) \,dx && (2) \end{align*} n→∞lim​yn​−yF(yn​)−F(y)​​=n→∞lim​∫I​yn​−yf(x,yn​)−f(x,y)​dx=∫I​n→∞lim​yn​−yf(yn​)−f(y)​dx=∫I​fy​(x,y)dx​​(3),DCT(2)​where the DCT applies because x↦f(x,yn)−f(x,y)yn−yx \mapsto\frac{f(x,y_{n})-f(x,y)}{y_{n}-y}x↦yn​−yf(x,yn​)−f(x,y)​ is integrable for all nnn, and they are dominated by h(x)h(x)h(x) for almost all xxx.

Product Measures

General Product Measures

  • Given measure spaces (Ω1,F1,m1)(\Omega_{1},\mathcal{F}_{1},m_{1})(Ω1​,F1​,m1​) and (Ω2,F2,m2)(\Omega_{2},\mathcal{F}_{2},m_{2})(Ω2​,F2​,m2​), their product measure space is (Ω,F,m)(\Omega,\mathcal{F},m)(Ω,F,m) where Ω=Ω1×Ω2\Omega=\Omega_{1}\times \Omega_{2}Ω=Ω1​×Ω2​ (the usual Cartesian product).
  • The simplest sets in F\mathcal{F}F are the “rectangles” A=A1×A2A=A_{1} \times A_{2}A=A1​×A2​, where Ai∈FiA_{i} \in F_{i}Ai​∈Fi​.
  • For a general set A∈FA \in \mathcal{F}A∈F, its section for ω1∈Ω1\omega_{1}\in \Omega_{1}ω1​∈Ω1​ is Aω1={ω2∈Ω2:(ω1,ω2)∈A}A_{\omega_{1}}=\{ \omega_{2} \in \Omega_{2}:(\omega_{1},\omega_{2}) \in A \}Aω1​​={ω2​∈Ω2​:(ω1​,ω2​)∈A}and similarly for ω2∈Ω2\omega_{2} \in \Omega_{2}ω2​∈Ω2​. In particular for rectangles, (A1×A2)ω2={A1if ω2∈A2∅if ω2∉A2(A_{1}\times A_{2})_{\omega_{2}}=\begin{cases} A_{1} & \text{if }\omega _{2} \in A_{2} \\ \emptyset &\text{if } \omega_{2} \not\in A_{2} \end{cases}(A1​×A2​)ω2​​={A1​∅​if ω2​∈A2​if ω2​∈A2​​
  • In the product measure space, the measure mmm is called the product measure, given by: m(A)=∫Ω2m1(Aω2) dm2m(A)=\int _{\Omega_{2}} m_{1}(A_{\omega_{2}})\, dm_{2} m(A)=∫Ω2​​m1​(Aω2​​)dm2​note that the integrand ω2↦m1(Aω2)\omega_{2} \mapsto m_{1}(A_{\omega_{2}})ω2​↦m1​(Aω2​​) is just a function Ω2→R\Omega_{2} \to \mathbb{R}Ω2​→R.
    • How do we know this a measure, and that integrating over Ω1\Omega_{1}Ω1​ instead gives the same value, you ask? Trust me bro. Or by reading the textbook.

Fubini’s and Tonelli’s Theorems

  • From now on, we only work with (R,MLeb,m)2(\mathbb{R},\mathcal{M}_{Leb},m)^{2}(R,MLeb​,m)2, and for clarity, the first space is labeled (Rx,Mx,m(x))(\mathbb{R}_{x},\mathcal{M}_{x},m(x))(Rx​,Mx​,m(x)), and the same for the second space with yyy.

  • Let f:R2→[0,∞]f: \mathbb{R}^{2} \to [0,\infty]f:R2→[0,∞] be measurable in the product measure, then:

    • For almost all yyy, mapping x↦f(x,y)x \mapsto f(x,y)x↦f(x,y) is measurable in m(x)m(x)m(x).
    • Mapping y↦∫Rxf(x,y) dm(x)y \mapsto \int_{\mathbb{R}_{x}} f(x,y) \, dm(x)y↦∫Rx​​f(x,y)dm(x) is measurable in m(y)m(y)m(y).
    • Integration in R2\mathbb{R}^{2}R2 equals a double integral: ∫R2f(x,y) d(x,y)=∫R(∫Rf(x,y) dx) dy\int _{\mathbb{R}^{2}}f(x,y) \, d(x,y) =\int _{\mathbb{R}} \left( \int _{\mathbb{R}}f(x,y) \, dx \right) \, dy ∫R2​f(x,y)d(x,y)=∫R​(∫R​f(x,y)dx)dywhere the inner integral can be seen as a function y↦∫Rf(x,y) dxy \mapsto \int _{\mathbb{R}} f(x,y) \, dxy↦∫R​f(x,y)dx.
    • Note that fff is non-negative.

  • Fubini’s Theorem: let f:R2↦Rf: \mathbb{R}^{2} \mapsto \mathbb{R}f:R2↦R be integrable in the product measure. Then ∫R(∫Rf(x,y) dx) dy=∫R2f(x,y) d(x,y)=∫R(∫Rf(x,y) dy) dx\int _{\mathbb{R}}\left( \int_{\mathbb{R}} f(x,y) \, dx \right) \, dy= \int _{\mathbb{R}^{2}}f(x,y) \, d(x,y)=\int _{\mathbb{R}}\left( \int_{\mathbb{R}} f(x,y) \, dy \right) \, dx ∫R​(∫R​f(x,y)dx)dy=∫R2​f(x,y)d(x,y)=∫R​(∫R​f(x,y)dy)dxand the double integrals exist, in the sense that (e.g. for LHS\mathrm{LHS}LHS)

    • The inner integrand x↦f(x,y)x \mapsto f(x,y)x↦f(x,y) is integrable in m(x)m(x)m(x), with integral F(y)≡∫Rf(x,y) dm(x)F(y) \equiv \int _{\mathbb{R}}f(x,y) \, dm(x)F(y)≡∫R​f(x,y)dm(x).
    • Integrating again, y↦F(y)y \mapsto F(y)y↦F(y) is integrable in m(y)m(y)m(y).

  • Tonelli’s Theorem: f:R2→Rf: \mathbb{R}^{2}\to \mathbb{R}f:R2→R is integrable if either of the following is: ∫R(∫R∣f∣ dx) dyOR∫R(∫R∣f∣ dy) dx\begin{align*} \int _{\mathbb{R}}\left( \int_{\mathbb{R}} |f| \, dx \right) \, dy &&\text{OR}&&\int _{\mathbb{R}}\left( \int_{\mathbb{R}} |f| \, dy \right) \, dx \end{align*}∫R​(∫R​∣f∣dx)dy​​OR​​∫R​(∫R​∣f∣dy)dx​so Fubini’s theorem applies to fff.

Spaces of Integrable Functions

Integrals as Norms

  • Given f∈L1(R)f \in \mathcal{L}^{1}(\mathbb{R})f∈L1(R), ∥f∥1≡∫∣f∣\|f\|_{1} \equiv\int |f|∥f∥1​≡∫∣f∣ has the desired properties of a norm, except that ∥f∥1=0⇏f≡0\|f\|_{1}=0 \not \Rightarrow f\equiv 0∥f∥1​=0⇒f≡0, but only a.e.\mathrm{a.e.}a.e..
  • The solution is to define the norm ∥∗∥1\|*\|_{1}∥∗∥1​ on space of equivalence classes of the relation ∼\sim∼, where f∼g  ⟺  f=g  a.e.f \sim g \iff f=g\,\, \mathrm{a.e.}f∼g⟺f=ga.e.and the quotient space L1=L1/{f:f=0  a.e.}L^{1}=\mathcal{L}^{1} / \{ f:f=0\,\,\mathrm{a.e.} \}L1=L1/{f:f=0a.e.} forms a normed space with ∥∗∥1\|*\|_{1}∥∗∥1​.
  • The same can be done with ∥f∥2≡∫∣f∣2\|f\|_{2}\equiv \sqrt{ \int |f|^{2} }∥f∥2​≡∫∣f∣2​ and L2={f:∥f∥2<∞}\mathcal{L}^{2}=\left\{ f: \|f\|_{2}<\infty \right\}L2={f:∥f∥2​<∞} by defining L2=L2/{f:f=0  a.e.}L^{2}=\mathcal{L}^{2} / \{ f:f=0\,\,\mathrm{a.e.} \}L2=L2/{f:f=0a.e.}.
  • The difference between Lp\mathcal{L}^{p}Lp and LpL^{p}Lp is not important, so it will be dropped.

General Lp Spaces and Inequalities

  • In fact, for general p>0p>0p>0, we can define ∥f∥p=(∫∣f∣p dx)1/p\|f\|_{p}=\left( \int |f|^p \, dx \right)^{1 / p}∥f∥p​=(∫∣f∣pdx)1/pand it forms a norm on the space Lp={f:∥f∥p<∞}\mathcal{L}^{p}=\{f:\|f\|_{p}<\infty \}Lp={f:∥f∥p​<∞}.

    • Its linearity is straightforward; the triangular inequality less so.

  • Minkowski’s inequality: for p≥1p\ge1p≥1, f,g∈Lpf,g \in \mathcal{L}^{p}f,g∈Lp, there is ∥f+g∥p<∥f∥p+∥g∥p\|f+g\|_{p}<\| f\|_{p}+\| g \|_{p}∥f+g∥p​<∥f∥p​+∥g∥p​.

  • Hölder’s Inequality: for 1<p,q<∞1<p,q<\infty1<p,q<∞ such that p−1+q−1=1p^{-1}+q^{-1}=1p−1+q−1=1, and f∈Lp,g∈Lqf \in \mathcal{L}^{p},g \in \mathcal{L}^{q}f∈Lp,g∈Lq, there is fg∈L1fg \in \mathcal{L}^{1}fg∈L1, and that ∥fg∥1≤∥f∥p∥g∥q\|fg\|_{1}\le \|f\|_{p}\|g\|_{q}∥fg∥1​≤∥f∥p​∥g∥q​

Both proofs are algebraic manipulations and use convexity. See notes or the textbook.

  • The space (Lp,∥∗∥)p(\mathcal{L}^{p},\| \ast \|)_{p}(Lp,∥∗∥)p​ is complete:
    • Any Cauchy sequence (fn)⊆Lp(f_{n}) \subseteq \mathcal{L}^{p}(fn​)⊆Lp converges in ∥∗∥p\| \ast \|_{p}∥∗∥p​ to a function f∈Lpf \in \mathcal{L}^{p}f∈Lp.
    • Also, there is a subsequence (fnk)→f  a.e.(f_{n_{k}}) \to f\,\,\mathrm{a.e.}(fnk​​)→fa.e. in pointwise convergence.

Maximum Norm

  • Instead of p<∞p<\inftyp<∞, letting p=∞p=\inftyp=∞ gives the norm ∥f∥∞=ess supf=inf⁡{c:f<c  a.e.}\|f\|_{\infty}=\mathrm{ess\,sup}f=\inf\{ c:f<c\,\,\mathrm{a.e.} \}∥f∥∞​=esssupf=inf{c:f<ca.e.}on the space L∞={f:∥f∥∞<∞}\mathcal{L}^{\infty}=\{ f:\|f\|_{\infty}<\infty \}L∞={f:∥f∥∞​<∞}, the set of essentially bounded functions.
